title: How to Avoid Impostors in the Practice of Magnetism, According to Raspail?
first_phrase: In the previous text, Raspail discussed the exploitation of somnambulism by impostors, making it difficult to distinguish truth from falsehood. In the last 200 tokens, he suggests that to prepare the way for discovery, one must first remove all mercantilism and self-interest from the experience. The magnetism should be presented as an act of charity, done for the benefit of others, and not for personal gain. Let the believers and the skeptics come forward to test the talisman, and the possessor must demonstrate the fact by submitting it to all tests without offense or bias. Raspail asserts that those who possess such a treasure cannot find pleasure in material things and must rise above human miseries.
content: Qu’il n’irnposc point de croyance, mais qu’il démontre le fait en le soumettant à toutes les épreuves et contre-épreuves, ne se lassant point de nos insistances, ne s’offensant pas de nos contradictions, se conservant pur de tout sentiment d’intérêt personnel, intérêt de cœur ou intérêt de bourse. Un homme qui possède en ses mains un pareil trésor ne doit plus pouvoir se tenir qu’à cent mille pieds au- L*«. _ OPINION DE RASPAIL SUR LE MAGNÉTISME dessus de nos misères humaines. Qu’a-t-il besoin, pour jouir, de notre volupté matérielle, lui dont la sensibilité aérienne semble rentrer en commerce avec les esprits et les dieux? Point do ces pastorales et de ces marivaudages de la sensiblerie ! Point de ces coups de théâtre qui mettraient en poudre, comme un verre, l’existence la plus robuste, s’ils étaient la pure et vive expression d’une émotion de bon aloi.
last_phrase: In conclusion, Raspail's opinion on magnetism highlights the importance of approaching facts with rigorous testing and an absence of personal interest, rather than blind belief or sensationalism. His warning against charlatanism and emphasis on scientific inquiry serve as a valuable lesson for readers seeking to understand the world with clarity and objectivity.
